title: R41521
content: The Continuing Appropriations Act, 2011 (P.L. 111-242) was amended in March 2011 to extend funding deadlines. Two additional amendments (P.L. 112-4 and P.L. 112-6) provided interim funding through April 8, 2011, cutting discretionary budget authority for FY2011 by $10 billion. This included reductions in funding for various programs and earmarks. The L-HHS-ED appropriations were reduced by $1.5 billion and $1.0 billion, respectively, according to the Congressional Budget Office. Program reductions totaling $10 billion were enacted in two CRs and were originally proposed in H.R. 1. The House passed H.R. 1 on February 19, 2011, which would have reduced overall non-emergency discretionary budget authority by $61.5 billion from FY2010 levels. The Senate rejected H.R. 1 and a substitute amendment offered by Senator Inouye, with funding reductions proposed in the Senate amendment below FY2010 levels. The House passed H.R. 1255 on April 1, 2011, which included potentially controversial policy riders affecting L-HHS-ED funding. The curr_chunk discusses prohibitions on spending for health care reform laws, funding for Planned Parenthood, and Department of Education rules on federal student aid. It also mentions CRS reports on FY2011 appropriations and related bills. The President signed H.R. 3081, the Continuing Appropriations Act, 2011, which provided temporary funding for government agencies until March 4, 2011. The law was amended multiple times to extend funding and provide for special situations. Funding levels were similar to FY2010 appropriations. The Senate Committee on Appropriations reported S. 3686 for FY2011 L-HHS-ED appropriations, recommending $171.1 billion in discretionary funds. The House L-HHS-ED Appropriations Subcommittee approved a draft bill but the full committee did not take further action. President Obama submitted his FY2011 budget to Congress, requesting $171.7 billion in discretionary funds for programs covered in the L-HHS-ED appropriations bill. The L-HHS-ED bill is a significant appropriations bill that funds various federal departments and agencies, including the Social Security Administration. It is known for its controversial nature due to funding size and program scope, with restrictions on federal funds for abortion and research on human embryos and stem cells. Discretionary funding in the bill is less than one-quarter of the total, making it the largest source of discretionary funds for domestic federal programs. The House and Senate Appropriations Committees determine maximum budget authority for annual appropriations acts under procedures laid out by the Congressional Budget Act of 1974. Congress establishes 302(a) allocations through the annual concurrent resolution on the budget, setting maximum spending totals for the appropriations committees. The Committees then subdivide their allocations to fund their bills. The House and Senate Appropriations Committees establish 302(b) allocations for each subcommittee, enforcing budget discipline by setting maximum discretionary budget authority. These allocations can be adjusted as appropriations bills progress. The allocations for FY2011 L-HHS-ED appropriations are shown in Table 5, with comparisons to FY2010. Both 302(a) and 302(b) allocations are often contested issues. Advance appropriations occur when funds are allocated. Advance appropriations occur when funds enacted in one fiscal year are not available for obligation until a subsequent fiscal year. For example, P.L. 111-117 provided $445 million for the Corporation for Public Broadcasting for use in FY2012. These appropriations help with long-term budget planning for recipients like state and local educational systems. However, the contentious aspect is how they are counted in budget ceilings, as they avoid current year limits but must be counted when first available for obligation. HHS program-specific spending plans and Recovery Act reports can be found online. Annual L-HHS-ED appropriations regularly include restrictions on federal funds for abortions. Restrictions on federal funds for abortions, known as the "Hyde Amendments," apply to L-HHS-ED funds, including Medicaid. Changes have been made over the years, allowing funding for abortions in cases of rape, incest, or life endangerment. The FY1998 and FY1999 appropriations extended these provisions to prohibit federal funds from buying managed care packages with abortion coverage, except in specific circumstances. The FY1998 Hyde Amendments added provisions to apply restrictions to all trust fund programs, including Medicare, and prohibited Medicare Advantage plans from requiring abortion services. The FY2005 L-HHS-ED appropriations added the "Weldon Amendment" to prevent discrimination against healthcare entities that do not provide abortion services. The FY2006 through FY2010 appropriations retained the Weldon amendment and Hyde restrictions. The current provisions can be found in §507 and §508 of P.L. 111-117. The Dickey Amendment, enacted in 1996, prohibits the use of funds for human embryo research. President Bush imposed restrictions on federal funding for stem cell research in 2001, which were lifted by President Obama in 2009. Key budget terms used in the report are based on CRS Report 98-720, Manual on the Federal Budget Process. Advance appropriation is budget authority that becomes available in a fiscal year beyond the one for which the appropriations act is enacted. Scorekeeping counts the entire amount in the fiscal year it first becomes available for obligation. Appropriation is budget authority that allows federal agencies to incur obligations and make payments for specified purposes. Annual appropriations are provided in appropriations acts, while most permanent appropriations are in substantive law. Major types of appropriations include regular, supplemental, and continuing. Budget authority is the legal authority to incur financial obligations. Budget authority includes appropriations, borrowing authority, and contract authority. It also covers the subsidy cost of direct loans and loan guarantees. The budget resolution outlines the congressional budget for at least five fiscal years, including various budget totals and functional allocations. Discretionary spending is annual appropriations, while entitlement authority allows payments to eligible recipients as legally binding obligations. Entitlement authority is a legally binding obligation funded by annual or permanent appropriations acts. Forward funding allows budget authority to be available into the next fiscal year. Mandatory spending is provided in laws other than annual appropriations acts. Rescission cancels previously enacted budget authority. Scorekeeping tracks congressional budgetary actions. Supplemental appropriations provide funds in addition to regular appropriations. Websites with information on budget and appropriations can be found at various sites for House and Senate Committees, Congressional Budget Office (CBO), Congressional Research Service (CRS), Government Accountability Office (GAO), Government Printing Office (GPO), and Office of Management and Budget (OMB). Statements of Administration Policy (SAPs) can also be accessed online.
